The canine tooth, also known as a cuspid or eye tooth, is the pointed tooth located between the incisors and premolars in humans and other mammals. It is so named because it resembles a dog's tooth.
Canines, or cuspids, are the sharp, pointed teeth located at the front of the mouth. They are named after the Latin word for dog, "canis," because of their resemblance to a dog's teeth.
